name: BBCWorld
text:
Wildlife populations have fallen by 68% since 1970, a major report by the conservation group WWF suggests

It warns nature is being destroyed so fast by human activity that it is "driving wildlife to extinction"

[Thread]

https://t.co/tBNuBnAFFl

name: BBCWorld
text:
The ‚Äúcatastrophic decline‚Äù shows no signs of slowing

Researchers say nature is being destroyed by humans at a rate never seen before

Wildlife is ‚Äúin freefall‚Äù as we burn forests, over-fish seas and destroy wild areas

https://t.co/tBNuBnAFFl https://t.co/dBur02b2NB

name: BBCWorld
text:
Some of the key problems with habitat change include:

- 1.9 square km of land lost, since 2000
- 1m species threatened with extinction
- 1.3bn tonnes of food wasted every year

https://t.co/tBNuBnAFFl https://t.co/8h9QjA3p4y

name: BBCWorld
text:
"We are wrecking our world - the one place we call home - risking our health, security and survival here on Earth," Tanya Steele, from WWF, warns

Experts say the decline is clear evidence of the damage human activity is doing to the natural world

https://t.co/tBNuBnAFFl https://t.co/iPqOIlOIK2

name: BBCWorld
text:
Evidence suggests we can halt, and even reverse habitat loss and deforestation if we take urgent action

‚ÄúDoing so will require systemic shifts in how we produce food, create energy manage our oceans and use materials,‚Äù Sir David Attenborough says

https://t.co/tBNuBnAFFl https://t.co/4XoAt86XQb

name: BBCWorld
text:
Prof Dame Georgina Mace says conservation actions alone won't be sufficient to "bend the curve on biodiversity loss"

"The food system will be particularly important, both from the agricultural sector on the supply side, and consumers on the demand side"

https://t.co/tBNuBnAFFl https://t.co/T7sUqeWSG9

name: BBCWorld
text: Read more about how wildlife is under pressure from habitat loss, including deforestation: https://t.co/tBNuBnAFFl
